markTypeDescriptions.packet: Marks individual packets only - Use for per-packet queue assignment and traffic shaping
markTypeDescriptions.routing: Marks routing decision - Use for policy-based routing, multi-WAN, and VRF

whatIsMangle.title: What is Mangle?
whatIsMangle.content: Mangle rules mark packets for Quality of Service (QoS), policy routing, and advanced traffic control. They don't block traffic - they classify it for other features to use.

packetFlow.title: Packet Flow
packetFlow.content: Packets flow through chains in this order: prerouting → [routing decision] → input/forward → output → postrouting. Mark packets early (prerouting) and match marks later for best performance.

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Mark VoIP traffic with high DSCP for QoS prioritization
Route specific traffic through different WAN connections (load balancing)
Apply connection marks for queue tree bandwidth management
Change MSS to prevent fragmentation on VPN tunnels
Mark gaming traffic for low-latency queuing

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Use connection marks (not packet marks) for QoS - more efficient
Mark in prerouting chain, match in other chains - faster processing
Enable passthrough on marking rules to continue processing
Use descriptive mark names (e.g., 'voip_traffic' not 'mark1')
Add comments to document rule purpose and dependencies
Test with disabled=yes first, then enable after verification

rateLimiting.title: Rate Limiting
rateLimiting.subtitle: Connection rate control and DDoS protection
rateLimiting.description: Protect against DDoS and connection flooding

actionDescriptions.drop: Silently drop connections exceeding the rate limit
actionDescriptions.tarpit: Slow down connections exceeding the rate limit (tarpit delay)
actionDescriptions.addToList: Add source IP to address list when rate limit is exceeded

fieldHelp.srcAddress: Leave empty or toggle 'Any Source IP' to apply rate limit to all IPs
fieldHelp.connectionLimit: Maximum number of connections allowed within the time window
fieldHelp.timeWindow: Time period for measuring connection rate (second/minute/hour)
fieldHelp.action: What to do when rate limit is exceeded
fieldHelp.addressList: Name of address list to add blocked IPs to (will be created if not exists)
fieldHelp.addressListTimeout: How long to keep IPs in the blocked list
fieldHelp.synLimit: Maximum SYN packets per second allowed from a single IP
fieldHelp.burst: Additional packets allowed in short bursts
fieldHelp.actionDrop: Recommended for severe attacks - drops connections immediately
fieldHelp.actionTarpit: Slows down attackers - useful for brute force protection
fieldHelp.actionAddToList: Flexible - allows dynamic blocking and whitelist management
fieldHelp.whitelistInfo: Whitelisted IPs bypass all rate limit rules

synFlood.warning: SYN flood protection blocks packets globally. Tune carefully.
synFlood.dangerConfirm: Enabling SYN flood protection may block legitimate high-traffic. Continue?
synFlood.title: SYN Flood Protection
synFlood.description: Protect against SYN flood attacks by limiting SYN packet rate
synFlood.whatIsSynFlood: What is a SYN Flood Attack?
synFlood.synFloodExplanation: A SYN flood attack exploits the TCP handshake by sending many SYN packets without completing the connection. This protection uses the RAW firewall table to drop excessive SYN packets before connection tracking, preventing resource exhaustion.
synFlood.rulePreviewDescription: This is the rule that will be created in the RAW firewall table

whatIsRateLimiting.title: What is Rate Limiting?
whatIsRateLimiting.content: Rate limiting restricts the number of connections from an IP address within a time period. It protects against DDoS attacks, brute force attempts, and connection flooding by automatically blocking or slowing down excessive connections.

actionTypes.title: Action Types
items: Drop: Immediately reject connections - best for severe attacks
Tarpit: Slow down connections - useful for brute force protection
Add to List: Flexible dynamic blocking - allows whitelist management

synFloodProtection.title: SYN Flood Protection
synFloodProtection.content: SYN flood attacks send many TCP SYN packets without completing the handshake, exhausting server resources. This protection uses the RAW firewall table to drop excessive SYN packets before connection tracking, preventing resource exhaustion with minimal performance impact.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Start with higher limits and adjust down based on legitimate traffic patterns
Use 'add-to-list' action for flexibility - allows whitelist management
Create a whitelist rule for trusted IPs (admin networks, monitoring services)
Monitor statistics regularly to identify attack patterns
Set appropriate timeouts - too short may allow rapid re-attacks
Test rules with disabled=yes first, then enable after verification
Document rules with comments explaining their purpose

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Protect SSH/RDP from brute force attacks (5-10 connections per minute)
Prevent HTTP flood attacks (100-500 connections per minute per IP)
Block port scanners (10-20 connections per second across all ports)
Protect mail servers from spam bots (20-50 connections per hour)
Defend against application-layer DDoS (50-100 connections per second)

raw.title: RAW Firewall Rules
raw.subtitle: Pre-connection tracking packet processing
raw.description: Process packets BEFORE connection tracking for performance optimization and DDoS protection

chainDescriptions.prerouting: Process incoming packets BEFORE routing decision and connection tracking
chainDescriptions.output: Process outgoing packets BEFORE connection tracking (packets originating from router)

actionDescriptions.drop: Drop packet immediately without connection tracking (saves CPU and memory)
actionDescriptions.accept: Accept packet and bypass RAW table processing (continue to connection tracking)
actionDescriptions.notrack: Skip connection tracking entirely for high-volume legitimate traffic
actionDescriptions.jump: Jump to another chain for additional processing
actionDescriptions.log: Log packet to system log before further processing

protectionLevel.label: Protection Level
protectionLevel.help: Higher levels provide stronger protection but may have false positives

review.title: Review & Apply

review.help: Check all settings before creating RAW rules

low.label: Low
low.description: Basic protection with minimal false positives

safetyConfirm.title: DDoS Protection Warning
safetyConfirm.message: DDoS protection rules drop packets before connection tracking. Misconfiguration can block legitimate traffic.
warnings: Test in a maintenance window or staging environment first
Monitor logs for false positives after enabling
Keep whitelist rules for trusted sources (management IPs)
Higher protection levels may affect legitimate burst traffic
safetyConfirm.checkbox: I understand the risks and have reviewed the configuration

bogon.title: Bogon Filter
bogon.subtitle: Block invalid source addresses
bogon.description: Drop packets from invalid, reserved, and private IP address ranges (RFC-defined bogon addresses)
bogon.warning: Blocking private ranges (192.168.x.x, 10.x.x.x, 172.16-31.x.x) will break LAN access. Only enable for WAN interfaces.

loopback.label: Loopback (127.0.0.0/8)
loopback.description: Block loopback addresses on external interfaces

multicast.label: Multicast (224.0.0.0/4)
multicast.description: Block multicast addresses on unicast interfaces

interfaceFilter.label: Apply to Interfaces
interfaceFilter.help: Select interfaces where bogon filtering should be applied (typically WAN only)

safetyConfirm.title: Bogon Filter Warning
safetyConfirm.message: Bogon filters block packets before connection tracking. Enabling private range blocking on LAN interfaces will break local network access.
warnings: NEVER enable private range blocking on LAN interfaces
Ensure management access is from whitelisted IPs
safetyConfirm.checkbox: I have verified interface selection and understand the risks

noMatchingRules.title: No Matching Rules

performance.title: Why use RAW table?
performance.subtitle: Performance optimization and DDoS protection
performance.explanation: The RAW table processes packets BEFORE connection tracking. This is critical for performance because connection tracking is expensive (CPU and memory). By dropping unwanted traffic in RAW, you prevent connection tracking overhead.

benefits.title: Key Benefits
items: Packets dropped in RAW bypass connection tracking entirely (saves CPU and memory)
Ideal for DDoS protection - drop attacks before they consume resources
Use 'notrack' action to bypass connection tracking for trusted high-volume traffic
Processes at the earliest point in packet flow for maximum efficiency
Reduces connection table size by preventing tracked connections for dropped packets

useCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: DDoS Protection - Drop SYN floods, UDP floods, ICMP floods before connection tracking
Bogon Filtering - Drop packets from invalid/reserved source addresses
Port Scan Protection - Drop packets from port scanners before connection tracking
High-Volume Traffic - Use 'notrack' for legitimate traffic that doesn't need connection tracking
Invalid Packets - Drop malformed packets before they reach connection tracking

tips.tip_drop: Use 'drop' action in RAW to bypass connection tracking and save CPU/memory
tips.tip_notrack: Use 'notrack' action for high-volume trusted traffic (e.g., monitoring systems)
tips.tip_order: Place RAW rules for common attacks at the top for fastest processing
tips.tip_logging: Enable logging temporarily to verify rules are matching correctly
tips.tip_testing: Test RAW rules carefully - they process BEFORE connection tracking and can break legitimate traffic

warnings.title: Important Warnings
items: RAW rules process BEFORE connection tracking - no connection state available
Cannot use connection state matching (established, related, etc.) in RAW
Dropped packets in RAW are invisible to connection tracking and firewall filter
Be careful with 'notrack' - untracked connections cannot use NAT or connection state matching
Always test RAW rules in a maintenance window or staging environment

hints.connectionTracking: RAW rules process BEFORE connection tracking - use for DDoS protection and performance optimization
hints.orderMatters: Rules are processed top-to-bottom - place common rules first for best performance
hints.dropVsNotrack: 'drop' removes packets entirely, 'notrack' bypasses connection tracking but allows packet to continue
hints.testing: Test RAW rules carefully - they can break legitimate traffic if misconfigured
hints.logging: Enable logging to debug rule matching and verify expected behavior

whatIsRaw.title: What is the RAW table?
whatIsRaw.content: The RAW table is the first firewall table in packet processing, executed BEFORE connection tracking. This makes it ideal for dropping unwanted traffic (DDoS attacks) before consuming CPU/memory resources, and for bypassing connection tracking for high-volume legitimate traffic.

packetFlow.title: RAW Packet Flow
packetFlow.content: Packets flow through RAW → Connection Tracking → Mangle → NAT → Filter. RAW is the earliest point, making it the most efficient place to drop unwanted traffic or bypass connection tracking.

connectionTracking.title: Connection Tracking Performance
connectionTracking.content: Connection tracking maintains state for every connection (TCP, UDP, ICMP), consuming CPU and memory. By dropping attacks in RAW or using 'notrack' for trusted traffic, you reduce connection tracking overhead and improve router performance.

ddosProtection.title: DDoS Protection with RAW
ddosProtection.content: RAW table is ideal for DDoS protection because it drops attack traffic BEFORE connection tracking. This prevents attackers from filling the connection table and consuming router resources. Use the DDoS Protection Wizard to configure common protections.

notrackAction.title: When to use 'notrack'
notrackAction.content: Use 'notrack' for high-volume legitimate traffic that doesn't need connection tracking (e.g., monitoring systems, logging servers, SNMP). This reduces connection table size and improves performance. WARNING: Untracked connections cannot use NAT or connection state matching in other tables.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Use RAW for DDoS protection and dropping attack traffic
Place most common rules at the top for best performance
Use 'notrack' for high-volume trusted traffic to reduce connection tracking overhead
Enable logging temporarily to verify rules are working correctly
Test RAW rules in a maintenance window - they can break legitimate traffic
Keep whitelist rules for management IPs at the top
Use Bogon Filter to drop packets from invalid source addresses
Monitor connection table size - RAW rules should reduce it significantly

nat.title: NAT Rules
nat.subtitle: Network Address Translation configuration
nat.description: Configure port forwarding, masquerading, and address translation for routing traffic between networks

chainDescriptions.srcnat: Modify source address for outgoing packets (masquerade, source NAT)
chainDescriptions.dstnat: Modify destination address for incoming packets (port forwarding, destination NAT)

actionDescriptions.masquerade: Replace source IP with outgoing interface address (dynamic IP)
actionDescriptions.src-nat: Replace source IP with specific address (static IP)
actionDescriptions.dst-nat: Replace destination IP and/or port (port forwarding)
actionDescriptions.redirect: Redirect to local port on the router

portForwardWizard.title: Port Forward Wizard
portForwardWizard.subtitle: Step-by-step port forwarding configuration
portForwardWizard.description: Configure port forwarding to expose internal services to the internet

external.description: Configure the external port and protocol that will be accessible from the internet
external.label: External Access
external.help: This is the port and protocol that internet users will connect to

internal.title: Internal Destination
internal.description: Configure the internal IP address and port where traffic will be forwarded
internal.label: Internal Destination
internal.help: This is the device and port on your local network that will receive the traffic

review.title: Review & Apply
review.description: Review your port forwarding configuration before applying
review.label: Review Configuration
review.help: Double-check all settings before creating the NAT rule

safetyConfirm.title: Security Warning
safetyConfirm.message: Port forwarding exposes internal services to the internet. This can create security risks if not properly configured.
warnings: Exposed services should have strong authentication
Keep forwarded services up-to-date with security patches
Consider using non-standard external ports to reduce scanning
Monitor logs for suspicious connection attempts
safetyConfirm.checkbox: I understand the security implications of port forwarding

hints.dragToReorder: Drag rules to reorder them - earlier rules are processed first
hints.terminalAction: This is a terminal action - processing will stop here
hints.unusedRule: This rule has never matched any packets - verify the matchers
hints.disabledRule: This rule is disabled and will not process any packets
hints.chainOrder: Chains are processed in order: prerouting → routing → output/postrouting
hints.masqueradePerformance: Masquerade is slightly slower than src-nat but ideal for dynamic IPs
hints.portForwardSecurity: Port forwarding exposes services to the internet - ensure proper authentication
hints.hairpinNAT: For internal access to port forwards, enable hairpin NAT in firewall settings

whatIsNAT.title: What is NAT?
whatIsNAT.content: Network Address Translation (NAT) modifies IP addresses and ports in packet headers. It enables multiple devices to share a single public IP address and allows port forwarding to internal servers.

chains.title: NAT Chains
chains.content: srcnat chain processes outgoing packets (masquerade, source NAT). dstnat chain processes incoming packets (port forwarding, destination NAT). Rules are evaluated in order from top to bottom.

masqueradeVsSrcNat.title: Masquerade vs Source NAT
masqueradeVsSrcNat.content: Masquerade automatically uses the outgoing interface IP address - ideal for dynamic IPs (DHCP, PPPoE). Source NAT uses a static IP address - slightly faster but requires manual configuration for IP changes.

portForwarding.title: Port Forwarding
portForwarding.content: Port forwarding (dst-nat) redirects incoming traffic from a public port to an internal IP and port. Essential for hosting servers, remote access, and gaming. Always secure forwarded services with strong authentication.

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Masquerade - Share internet connection with local network devices
Port Forward - Host web servers, game servers, security cameras
Redirect - Transparent proxy, local DNS interception
Source NAT - Static outgoing IP for VPN or specific applications
Netmap - One-to-one mapping for subnet translation

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Use masquerade for dynamic WAN IPs, src-nat for static IPs
Place more specific rules before general rules (order matters)
Add comments to document the purpose of each rule
Test port forwards with disabled=yes first, then enable
Use non-standard external ports to reduce automated scanning
Enable logging for critical port forwards to monitor access
Combine with firewall filter rules for additional security
Consider VPN instead of port forwarding when possible

hints.referencingRules: Shows how many firewall rules reference this address list

whatAreAddressLists.title: What are Address Lists?
whatAreAddressLists.content: Address lists are collections of IP addresses, subnets, or ranges that can be used in firewall rules. They simplify rule management by allowing you to reference a named list instead of individual IPs.

staticVsDynamic.title: Static vs Dynamic Entries
staticVsDynamic.content: Static entries are manually added and remain until deleted. Dynamic entries are added automatically by firewall rules (e.g., blocking IPs that exceed rate limits) and can have timeouts.

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Blocklists - Block traffic from known malicious IPs
Allowlists - Allow traffic only from trusted IPs
Rate limiting - Automatically add IPs exceeding connection limits
Geographic blocking - Block entire country IP ranges
Internal networks - Group internal subnets for firewall rules

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Use descriptive list names (e.g., 'trusted_networks' not 'list1')
Add comments to document why each IP is in the list
Use timeouts for dynamic blocking to prevent permanent blocks
Regularly review and clean up unused address lists
Export address lists regularly as backups
Use CIDR notation for subnets instead of individual IPs when possible

servicePorts.title: Service Ports
servicePorts.description: Define service names for easier rule creation

validation.nameInvalid: Name must be alphanumeric with optional hyphens/underscores
validation.portExists: Port already assigned to another service
validation.groupEmpty: Group must contain at least one service
validation.descriptionTooLong: Description must be less than 500 characters

placeholders.selectServices: Select services to include in group

emptyStates.noServicesDescription: Add custom services to use in firewall rules
emptyStates.noGroupsDescription: Create groups to quickly select multiple services

tooltips.builtInReadOnly: Built-in services cannot be edited or deleted
tooltips.groupsMultiModeOnly: Service groups only work in multi-port mode

confirmations.deleteServiceDescription: This action cannot be undone. The service will be removed from your custom list.
confirmations.deleteGroupDescription: This action cannot be undone. The group will be removed but individual services will remain.

connections.title: Connection Tracking
connections.subtitle: Active firewall connections and tracking settings
connections.description: Monitor active connections and configure connection tracking settings for stateful firewall operation

stateDescriptions.established: Connection is fully established and actively transmitting data
stateDescriptions.related: Related to an existing connection (e.g., FTP data channel)
stateDescriptions.new: New connection attempt not yet established
stateDescriptions.invalid: Invalid or malformed connection that doesn't match any known state
stateDescriptions.untracked: Connection not being tracked by the firewall

filterHelp.ipAddress: Supports wildcards: 192.168.1.* matches all IPs in that subnet
filterHelp.protocol: Filter by connection protocol (TCP, UDP, ICMP)
filterHelp.state: Filter by connection state (established, new, related, etc.)

killConnection.title: Terminate Connection
killConnection.description: Are you sure you want to terminate this connection?
killConnection.warning: This will immediately terminate the active connection.
consequences: The connection will be removed from the tracking table
Any active data transfer will be interrupted
The client will need to establish a new connection

table.noMatches: No connections match the current filters

settings.title: Connection Tracking Settings
settings.description: Configure connection tracking behavior and timeout values

general.title: General Settings
general.enabledHelp: Enable or disable connection tracking globally
general.maxEntriesHelp: Maximum number of connections in the tracking table (1-10,000,000)
general.looseTrackingHelp: Allow TCP connections without proper handshake (not recommended for security)

tcpTimeouts.title: TCP Timeouts
tcpTimeouts.description: Configure timeout values for different TCP connection states
tcpTimeouts.establishedHelp: Timeout for established TCP connections (default: 1 day)
tcpTimeouts.synSentHelp: Timeout for connections in SYN-SENT state (default: 5 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.synReceivedHelp: Timeout for connections in SYN-RECEIVED state (default: 60 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.finWaitHelp: Timeout for connections in FIN-WAIT state (default: 10 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.timeWaitHelp: Timeout for connections in TIME-WAIT state (default: 10 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.closeHelp: Timeout for connections in CLOSE state (default: 10 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.closeWaitHelp: Timeout for connections in CLOSE-WAIT state (default: 10 seconds)
tcpTimeouts.lastAckHelp: Timeout for connections in LAST-ACK state (default: 10 seconds)

otherProtocols.title: Other Protocol Timeouts
otherProtocols.description: Configure timeout values for non-TCP protocols

durationFormat.title: Duration Format
durationFormat.description: Enter durations using combinations of days (d), hours (h), minutes (m), and seconds (s)
durationFormat.examples: Examples: 1d (1 day), 12h (12 hours), 30m (30 minutes), 45s (45 seconds), 1d12h30m (1 day, 12 hours, 30 minutes)

validation.maxEntriesMin: Maximum entries must be at least 1
validation.maxEntriesInteger: Maximum entries must be a whole number
validation.portInvalid: Port must be a number between 1 and 65535

noConnections.title: No Active Connections
noConnections.description: There are currently no active connections being tracked by the firewall.
noConnections.hint: Connections will appear here as devices communicate through the router.

filterNoResults.title: No Matching Connections
filterNoResults.description: No connections match your current filters. Try adjusting the filter criteria.

hints.autoRefresh: Connections auto-refresh every 5 seconds - pause to inspect details
hints.wildcards: Use wildcards (*) in IP filters to match subnets (e.g., 192.168.1.*)
hints.killConnection: Killing a connection may disrupt active transfers and services
hints.looseTracking: Loose tracking is less secure but may be needed for asymmetric routing
hints.timeoutSettings: Lower timeouts free up tracking table entries faster but may break long-lived connections
hints.maxEntries: If the tracking table fills up, new connections will be dropped

whatIsConnectionTracking.title: What is Connection Tracking?
whatIsConnectionTracking.content: Connection tracking maintains a table of active network connections, enabling stateful firewall operation. It tracks the state of each connection (new, established, related) and automatically handles return traffic for established connections.

connectionStates.title: Connection States
connectionStates.content: Connections progress through states: new (initial packet), established (handshake complete), related (associated with existing connection), and various TCP-specific states (SYN-SENT, FIN-WAIT, TIME-WAIT, etc.).

timeoutSettings.title: Timeout Settings
timeoutSettings.content: Timeouts determine how long inactive connections remain in the tracking table. Lower timeouts free up resources faster but may prematurely close long-lived connections. Higher timeouts use more memory but accommodate idle connections.

maxEntries.title: Maximum Entries
maxEntries.content: The maximum entries setting limits the size of the connection tracking table. If the table fills up, new connections will be rejected. Monitor your connection count and adjust this limit based on your network size and available RAM.

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Monitor active connections to detect unusual traffic patterns
Identify connection leaks from misconfigured applications
Troubleshoot connectivity issues by inspecting connection states
Terminate stuck connections that aren't closing properly
Adjust timeouts to optimize memory usage vs connection stability

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Keep connection tracking enabled for stateful firewall operation
Set max entries to 2-3x your typical peak connection count
Use default timeouts unless you have specific requirements
Enable loose tracking only if you have asymmetric routing
Monitor connection count regularly to detect anomalies
Use filters to investigate suspicious connection patterns
Document any timeout adjustments and the reason for them

logs.title: Firewall Logs
logs.subtitle: Real-time firewall activity and traffic logging
logs.description: Monitor firewall activity, blocked connections, and traffic patterns in real-time
logs.empty: No firewall logs available. Enable logging in your firewall rules to see activity.

table.noMatches: No logs match the current filters

logDetails.title: Log Entry Details
logDetails.description: Complete details for this firewall log entry

exportLogs.title: Export Firewall Logs
exportLogs.description: Export filtered logs to CSV or JSON format

addToBlocklist.title: Add to Blocklist
addToBlocklist.description: Add IP address to firewall blocklist

noLogs.title: No Firewall Logs
noLogs.description: Enable logging in your firewall rules to monitor traffic and security events.

noLogsInRange.title: No Logs in Time Range
noLogsInRange.description: No firewall logs found for the selected time range. Try expanding the time range or adjusting filters.

filterNoResults.title: No Matching Logs
filterNoResults.description: No logs match your current filters. Try adjusting the filter criteria.

error.addToBlocklist: Failed to add IP to blocklist

hints.enableLogging: Enable logging on firewall rules to populate this view
hints.logPrefix: Use log prefixes to identify which rule generated each log entry
hints.performance: Logging all traffic can impact router performance - use selectively
hints.retention: Logs are stored for 7 days by default - export for longer retention
hints.filtering: Use filters to narrow down logs by time, action, or IP address

whatAreFirewallLogs.title: What are Firewall Logs?
whatAreFirewallLogs.content: Firewall logs record traffic events matching firewall rules with logging enabled. They help monitor security events, troubleshoot connectivity issues, and analyze traffic patterns.

logPrefix.title: Log Prefixes
logPrefix.content: Log prefixes are custom labels added to log entries to identify which firewall rule generated the log. Use descriptive prefixes like 'DROP_WAN_' or 'ACCEPT_VPN_' to quickly identify rule matches.

commonUseCases.title: Common Use Cases
items: Monitor blocked connection attempts from the internet
Troubleshoot connectivity issues by logging accepted connections
Identify port scan attempts and malicious traffic patterns
Track internal traffic for compliance and auditing
Debug firewall rules during initial configuration

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Use specific log prefixes for each rule for easy identification
Log drop/reject rules on WAN interfaces to monitor attacks
Avoid logging all accepted traffic - impacts performance
Use log prefixes that indicate chain and purpose (e.g., 'INPUT_DROP_SSH')
Export logs regularly for long-term analysis and compliance
Filter logs by time range to reduce load when analyzing
Add suspicious IPs to blocklists directly from log view

portKnocking.title: Port Knocking
portKnocking.subtitle: Protect services behind secret knock sequences
portKnocking.description: Hide sensitive services by requiring a secret sequence of connection attempts before granting access

infoCard.title: What is Port Knocking?
infoCard.description: Port knocking hides services by requiring a secret sequence of connection attempts to specific ports before granting access. This prevents port scanning and unauthorized access to sensitive services like SSH.

fieldHelp.name: Unique identifier for this knock sequence (used in address list names)
fieldHelp.knockPorts: Secret sequence of ports to knock. Minimum 2 ports required.
fieldHelp.protectedPort: Service port to protect behind the knock sequence
fieldHelp.protectedProtocol: Protocol of the protected service (TCP or UDP)
fieldHelp.accessTimeout: Duration of access after successful knock
fieldHelp.enabled: Enable or disable this knock sequence

warnings.sshLockout: Warning: This sequence protects SSH (port 22). Ensure you test the knock sequence before logging out to avoid being locked out.
warnings.sshLockoutDelete: Warning: This sequence protects SSH. Ensure you have alternative access before deleting.
warnings.testBeforeLogout: Test before logging out to avoid lockout

create.title: Create Port Knock Sequence
create.description: Define a secret knock sequence to protect a service

delete.title: Delete Port Knock Sequence
delete.description: Are you sure you want to delete the sequence "{{name}}"? This will remove all associated firewall rules.

noSequences.title: No Port Knock Sequences
noSequences.description: Create a knock sequence to protect sensitive services.

noAttempts.title: No Knock Attempts
noAttempts.description: Knock attempts will appear here when sequences are triggered.

error.create: Failed to create port knock sequence
error.update: Failed to update port knock sequence
error.delete: Failed to delete port knock sequence
error.toggle: Failed to toggle port knock sequence
error.load: Failed to load port knock sequences

validation.nameInvalid: Name must contain only letters, numbers, underscores, and hyphens
validation.nameTooLong: Name must be 63 characters or less
validation.knockPortsRequired: At least 2 knock ports are required

counters.title: Traffic Counters
counters.subtitle: Rule hit statistics and visualization
counters.description: Monitor traffic patterns and rule effectiveness with real-time counter visualization

settings.title: Counter Settings
settings.pollingIntervalHelp: How often to refresh counter values
settings.showRelativeBarHelp: Display progress bars showing relative traffic volume
settings.showRateHelp: Display packets/bytes per second on desktop view

export.title: Export Counter Data
export.description: Export traffic statistics to CSV format

noData.title: No Traffic Data
noData.description: This rule has not matched any traffic yet.
noData.hint: Traffic counters will update as packets match this rule.

noHistory.title: No Historical Data
noHistory.description: Historical tracking has not been enabled or no data has been collected yet.
noHistory.hint: Counter history is stored locally for 7 days.

hints.relativeBar: Bar length shows traffic volume relative to busiest rule
hints.rateCalculation: Rate is calculated from recent changes in counter values
hints.unusedRule: This rule has never matched any packets - verify matchers
hints.pollingImpact: Lower polling intervals increase router load but provide more real-time data

efficiency.title: Rule Efficiency Report
efficiency.subtitle: Optimize firewall performance
efficiency.description: Analyze firewall rules for redundancies and optimization opportunities

redundancy.title: Redundant Rules
redundancy.description: Rules that are superseded by other rules or never match traffic
redundancy.noSuggestions: No redundant rules detected. Your firewall configuration is optimal!

reordering.title: Reordering Suggestions
reordering.description: Rules that could be reordered for better performance
reordering.noSuggestions: Rule order is optimal. No reordering suggestions.

details.ruleConflict: This rule is superseded by rule #{{position}}
details.highTrafficLatePosition: Rule #{{position}} has {{ratio}}x more traffic but appears later in chain
details.neverMatched: This rule has never matched any traffic
details.sameAction: Multiple rules with same action and overlapping criteria
details.addressOverlap: Address ranges overlap with another rule

applySuggestion.title: Apply Suggestion
applySuggestion.description: Are you sure you want to apply this optimization?
applySuggestion.deleteWarning: This will delete the selected rule permanently.
applySuggestion.disableWarning: This will disable the selected rule.
applySuggestion.reorderWarning: This will reorder rules in the {{chain}} chain.
consequences: Rule order will change immediately
Traffic matching may be affected
Test the configuration after applying

preview.title: Preview Suggestion
preview.description: View the proposed changes before applying

noRules.title: No Rules to Analyze
noRules.description: Add firewall rules to see efficiency suggestions.

optimalConfiguration.title: Optimal Configuration
optimalConfiguration.description: No optimization suggestions found. Your firewall rules are well-configured!
optimalConfiguration.hint: Regular analysis helps maintain optimal performance as traffic patterns change.

hints.regularAnalysis: Run efficiency analysis regularly as traffic patterns change
hints.testAfterChanges: Test firewall configuration after applying suggestions
hints.highSeverityFirst: Address high severity suggestions first for best results
hints.backupBeforeChanges: Consider backing up configuration before applying multiple suggestions
hints.trafficBased: Suggestions are based on actual traffic counters - enable counter tracking for accurate analysis

whatIsEfficiencyReport.title: What is the Efficiency Report?
whatIsEfficiencyReport.content: The efficiency report analyzes your firewall rules to identify redundancies and suboptimal ordering. It uses actual traffic counters to suggest improvements that can enhance performance and reduce resource usage.

redundancyDetection.title: Redundancy Detection
redundancyDetection.content: Redundant rules are those that will never match traffic because they are superseded by earlier rules with the same or broader criteria. Removing redundant rules simplifies configuration and slightly improves performance.

reorderingSuggestions.title: Reordering Suggestions
reorderingSuggestions.content: Rules are processed in order from top to bottom. Placing high-traffic rules earlier in the chain reduces the number of rule evaluations per packet, improving firewall performance. The report identifies rules that would benefit from reordering.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
items: Run efficiency analysis weekly or after significant rule changes
Address high severity suggestions promptly
Test configuration in a maintenance window after applying changes
Enable counter tracking for accurate traffic-based analysis
Preview suggestions before applying to understand the impact
Keep comments on rules to document optimization decisions
